ALLEGATION:
Youth Z stole keys from Methodist and ran away allegedly because he was afraid
after Staff 1 threatened to have people come to the facility, beat him, and shoot
him.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was received by DCWL on 11/9/22. The complainant, who is also foster
care staff, was notified via email and provided the current location of the youth.
On 11/9/22, Chief Administrator 1 clarified the car keys stolen were taken from the child
placing agency’s office building and not from the residential facility. However, as an
added precaution, both programs installed lock boxes on 11/11/22 where they now
store the keys.
On 11/10/22 at 10:55am, I interviewed Youth Z, age 12, jointly with Government
Worker 1 in a hospital emergency room in Lansing. He had been there for a few days
awaiting a psychiatric evaluation. I introduced myself and the government worker.
Youth Z was asleep and became irritated and refused to wake up for an interview. We
left the room for a few minutes then returned and tried again. Youth Z still refused to
wake up and talk to us. I asked him what the staff at Methodist said or did that caused
him to run away. Youth Z shouted angrily, “Nothing. Nothing.”
On 12/5/22, Government Worker 1 interviewed Youth Z again in the emergency room.
At that time, he stated that Staff 1 had threatened him three months prior to this
complaint, on 8/7/22, just before he AWOLed. He alleged that Staff 1 cussed at and
threatened Youths O and B as well but would not specify what Staff 1 said. Youth Z
also claimed that after he returned from one of his AWOLs, an unidentified staff refused
to let him into the cottage.
Government Worker 1 asked Youth Z how he stole a Methodist vehicle. He told her he
left the campus, returned later, broke into Methodist’s child placing agency office
building and stole car keys. Youth Z was found by police driving the child placing
agency’s vehicle in the community and was brought back to the residential program.
Methodist’s residential staff did not see the youth return to the property or take the
vehicle belonging to the child placing agency.
3

I reviewed Youth Z’s AWOL incident report dated 8/7/22 at 6:20pm authored by Staff 3.
The report indicated “No known triggers. Youth Z sat down, ate dinner, walked around
the cottage…then he walked out of the cottage with Staff 3 behind him. Youth returned
to the cottage at 10pm, was searched by staff with no further issues.”
I requested Youth Z’s AWOL history. Records indicate Youth Z was admitted to
Methodist Children’s Home on 8/1/22 and AWOLed eleven times in the three months he
was there. He left the campus without permission and returned or was brought back by
staff within an hour on 9/6/22, 9/11/22, 10/11/22 and 10/25/22. He left the campus for
over an hour and missing person’s reports were filed on 8/7/22, 9/7/22, 9/27/22,
10/3/22, 11/2/22, 11/5/22 and 11/6/22. Chief Administrator (CA) was unaware of any
times when staff refused to allow Youth Z back into the cottage after he returned from
AWOL.
I interviewed Staff 1 collaboratively with Government Worker 1. She has worked at the
facility for four years but has only worked with Youth Z for the last two months. Staff 1
described Youth Z as “difficult, physically aggressive, AWOLs every day, and does not
follow rules.” On 11/6/22, she said Youth Z woke up, used the bathroom, and took his
medication. “Next (from the window) I saw him walking across the campus.” Staff 1
and Staff 2 were both in the cottage. Staff 1 denied threatening Youth Z in any way
before he walked away. She also denied hearing Staff 2 threaten him.
I interviewed Staff 2 collaboratively with Government Worker 1 via telephone. She has
worked midnight shift at the facility for 21 years. Staff 2 said she did not recall Youth Z
AWOLing on 11/6/22, adding “He’s AWOLed so many times.” Staff 2 denied ever
threatening Youth Z and also denied ever hearing Staff 1 threaten him.
I interviewed Youth B collaboratively with Government Worker 1. He refused to provide
his birthdate or any other information.
I interviewed Youth E, age 10, collaboratively with Government Worker 1. He resided
in the same cottage as Youth Z. Youth E described Youth Z as “horrible, he physically
fights staff.” He denied ever hearing any staff threaten Youth Z. Youth E described
Staff 1 as “nice.”
On 12/7/22, the foster care worker expressed a new concern that Youth Z was not
searched or not searched properly upon returning from AWOL on 11/6/22.
I reviewed Youth Z’s AWOL return report dated 11/6/22 at 2:30am authored by Midnight
Supervisor. The report indicated “Walled Lake Police brought Youth Z back to the
campus. Writer searched Youth Z, escorted him inside then he went to his room to bed
for the night.”
I reviewed the facility’s search policy. It indicates “direct care staff can search a youth
upon his return from AWOL. There are two types of searches – Level 1 and Level 2.
4

Level 1 search is least restrictive: this is a ‘soft’ search and always occurs prior to a
Level 2 search.
• Ask the young person to flip out the inside of pockets
• Ask the young person to empty backpack
• Allow staff to visually inspect backpack as needed.
Level 2 search: This is a more restrictive approach based upon positive findings on
Level 1, resistance or continued probable cause. This is completed by the shift
supervisor or another residential supervisor and can include a pat-down search.
• Always use the back (not front) of your hands utilizing rubber gloves as needed
• Ask the young person to flip or undo waistbands while staff observes
• Ask the youth person to remove shoes – Staff should visually inspect each shoe for
contraband
• Ask socks to be removed for visual inspection as well
There was no evidence Midnight Supervisor failed to follow the search protocol.
I interviewed Youth O at school on 12/08/22. He resided in the same cottage as Youth
Z. Youth O described Youth Z as a “mean bully” who AWOLed a lot. He denied Staff 1
threatens or cusses at him or other children. He also denied that any staff refuse to let
children inside the cottage when they return from AWOL.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency’s
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: Methodist’s child caring institution staff are not responsible for
supervising youth who leave the property and sneak back on
campus unnoticed. They also are not responsible for
safeguarding the building, keys or vehicles belonging to the
child placing agency.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
5

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
(1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow
written policies and procedures that prohibit the following
forms of intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but
not limited to:
(iii) Threats of restraint, seclusion, punishment, or
otherwise suggesting physical or emotional harm to a
youth.
ANALYSIS: Initially Youth Z denied any staff threatened him or caused him
to AWOL from the facility on 11/6/22. Several weeks later he
claimed that Staff 1 threatened him before he AWOLed on
8/7/22. All youth and staff interviewed denied hearing Staff 1
threaten Youth Z or any other youth at any time.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend this facility continue its current licensing status.
